case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Lala Manmohan Das

facts.text: Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lala Manmohan Das was appointed treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain branches, sub-agencies and pay offices.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lala Manmohan Das - hereinafter called the assessee was appointed treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain branches, sub-agencies and pay offices.

facts.text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: In the previous year corresponding to the assessment year 1950-51, the assessee suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027.

anchor.surface_text: In the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51, the assessee, in performing his duties as a treasurer, suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assessee showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as treasurer of the Patna branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an assistant cashier.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assessee showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as treasurer of the Patna branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an assistant cashier.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the loss suffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the losssuffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank.

facts.text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off against the assessee's income from that source in the year under consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off against the assessees income from that source in the year under companysideration.

facts.text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., the following questions were referred to the High Court of Allahabad under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., the following questions were referred to the High Court of Allahabad under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: The High Court held that the remuneration received by the assessee from the Allahabad Bank was income liable to be taxed under section 10 of the Income-tax Act, and that the assessee could claim to set off the loss computed in the assessment year 1950-51 against the profits in the subsequent year.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the remuneration received by the assessee from the Allahabad Bank was income liable to be taxed under section 10 of the Income-tax Act, and that the assessee companyld claim to set off the loss companyputed in the assessment year 1950-51 against the profits in the subsequent year.

facts.text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: In making his order of assessment for the year 1950-51, the Income-tax Officer declared that the loss computed in that year could not be carried forward to the next year under section 24(2) of the Income-tax Act, as it was not a business loss.

facts.text: The remuneration of the treasurer shall be a monthly allowance for each of the branches, sub-agencies and pay offices the total of such monthly allowance to be Rs. 2,250 plus Rs. 350 for travelling expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the treasurer shall be a monthly allowance for each of the branches, sub-agencies and pay offices the total of such monthly allowance to be Rs. 2,250  Rupees two thousand two hundred and fifty  plus Rs. 350  Rupees three hundred and fifty  for travelling expenses.

facts.text: The treasurer shall serve the bank as treasurer for its branches, sub-agencies and pay offices until this agreement is determined as hereinafter provided.

anchor.surface_text: The treasurer shall serve the bank as treasurer for its branches, sub-agencies and pay offices until this agreement is determined as hereinafter provided.

facts.text: The treasurer shall with the approval of the bank appoint at adequate salaries to be paid by the bank all the Indian staff as may be considered sufficient by the bank for the business of the cash department.

anchor.surface_text: The treasurer shall with the approval of the bank appoint at adequate salaries to be paid by the bank all the Indian staff as may be companysidered sufficient by the bank for the business of the cash department of the banks branches, sub-agencies and pay offices

facts.text: The treasurer shall be responsible to the bank for the work and conduct of every person to be appointed or employed on his staff and shall make good to the bank any loss or damage sustained or incurred by the bank from any embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, mis-conduct, mistake, omission, negligent act or default of any such person or persons.

anchor.surface_text: The treasurer shall be responsible to the bank for the work and companyduct of every person to be appointed or employed on his staff and shall make good to the bank any loss or damage sustained or incurred by the bank from any embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, mis-conduct, mistake, omission, negligent act or default of any such person or persons.

facts.text: The treasurers employment may be determined at any time by either party giving to the other three calendar months written notice to that effect.

anchor.surface_text: The treasurers employment may be determined at any time by either party giving to the other three calendar months written numberice to that effect, and in the case of the treasurers death, this agreement as regards the treasurers liabilities and obligations for the staff and other persons shall remain in force

facts.text: The agreement contains certain peculiar covenants for instance, the expression treasurer includes the heirs and representatives.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement companytains certain peculiar companyenants for instance, the expression treasurer includes the heirs and representatives and except where the companytext may justify a companytrary implication, the rights, obligations and liabilities of the treasurer would apparently be enforceable by or be enforced against the heirs and legal representatives of the assessee.

facts.text: The treasurer is responsible for the acts of the Indian staff at the Branches, SubAgencies and Pay Offices as far apart as Calcutta, Lahore, Lucknow, Patna, Amritsar, Benaras and Secunderabad.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the treasurer was not a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was not salaries within the meaning of section 7 of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such treasurer fell to be computed under section 10 of the Act or section 7 or section 12 of the Income-tax Act ?

precedents.citation: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra

anchor.surface_text: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra observed The principles according to which the relationship as between employer and employee or master and servant has got to be determined are well settled. The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done. A distinction is also drawn between a contract for service and a contract of service and that distinction is put in this way In the one case the master can order or require what is to be done while in the other case he can not only order or require what is to be done but how itself it shall be done.

precedents.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd v State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: The test to determine employer-employee relationship is the existence of a right of control over the manner in which work is done; distinction between contract for service and contract of service.
precedents.cited_holding: The nature or extent of control requisite to establish employer-employee relationship varies and is a question of fact based on circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Simmons v. Heath Laundry Company it is impossible to lay down any rule of law distinguishing the one from the other. It is a question of fact to be decided by all the circumstances of the case. The greater the amount of direct control exercised over the person rendering the services by the person contracting for them the stronger the grounds for holding it to be a contract of service, and similarly the greater the degree of independence of such control the greater the probability the services rendered are of the nature of professional services and that the contract is not one of service.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether a relationship is one of employer-employee is a question of fact decided by all circumstances; degree of control indicates nature of contract.

precedents.citation: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd., and Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, treasurers were held merely to be servants of the banks, business whereof they attended. It is true that in each of these cases this court, in interpreting a contract in which a treasurer was appointed to supervise the cash department of a bank, held that the treasurer was a servant of the bank, and not an independent contractor.

precedents.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v Punjab National Bank Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Treasurer appointed to supervise cash department of bank is servant of the bank and not independent contractor.
precedents.cited_holding: Under the agreement, treasurer was servant of bank; staff under bank's control.

precedents.citation: Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, treasurers were held merely to be servants of the banks, business whereof they attended. It is true that in each of these cases this court, in interpreting a contract in which a treasurer was appointed to supervise the cash department of a bank, held that the treasurer was a servant of the bank, and not an independent contractor.

precedents.case_name: Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Treasurer of bank is servant; remuneration is salary under section 7, not business income under section 10.
precedents.cited_holding: Given bank's control and supervision over treasurer and power to terminate forthwith, treasurer is servant.

anchor.surface_text: A decision recorded by the Income-tax Officer who computes the loss in the previous year under s. 24 3  that the loss cannot be set off against the income of the subsequent year is number binding on the assessee.

The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

Whether the loss of profits or gains in any year may be carried forward to the following year and set off against his profits and gains, if any, from the same business, profession or vocation under s. 24 2  has to be determined by the Income-tax Officer who deals with,the assessment of the subsequent year.

The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. 10 of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.
